description: From Middle English given, from Old Norse gefa (“to give”), from Proto-Germanic *gebaną (“to give”). Merged with native Middle English yiven, ȝeven, from Old English ġiefan, from the same Proto-Germanic source (compare the obsolete inherited English doublet yive).

entries.meaning: The amount of bending that something undergoes when a force is applied to it; a tendency to yield under pressure; resilience.
examples: This chair doesn't have much give.
There is no give in his dogmatic religious beliefs.

verbs.description: give (third-person singular simple present gives, present participle giving, simple past gave, past participle given)

definitionGroups.group: (ditransitive) To move, shift, provide something abstract or concrete to someone or something or somewhere.

entries.meaning: To transfer one's possession or holding of (something) to (someone).
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:give
Antonyms: get, obtain, receive, take
I gave him my coat.
I gave my coat to the beggar.
When they asked, I gave my coat.

entries.meaning: To make a present or gift of.
examples: I'm going to give my wife a necklace for her birthday.
She gave a pair of shoes to her husband for their anniversary.
He gives of his energies to the organization.

entries.meaning: To pledge.
examples: I gave him my word that I'd protect his children.

entries.meaning: To provide (something) to (someone), to allow or afford.
examples: I gave them permission to miss tomorrow's class.
Please give me some more time.

entries.meaning: To cause (a sensation or feeling) to exist in.
examples: It gives me a lot of pleasure to be here tonight.
The fence gave me an electric shock.
My mother-in-law gives me nothing but grief.
It's giving me bad vibes.

entries.meaning: To carry out (a physical interaction) with (something).
examples: I want to give you a kiss.
She gave him a hug.
I'd like to give the tire a kick.
I gave the boy a push on the swing.
She gave me a wink afterwards, so I knew she was joking.

entries.meaning: To pass (something) into (someone's hand, etc.).
examples: Give me your hand.
On entering the house, he gave his coat to the doorman.

entries.meaning: To cause (a disease or condition) in, or to transmit (a disease or condition) to.
examples: My boyfriend gave me chlamydia.
He was convinced that it was his alcoholism that gave him cancer.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide, as, a service or a broadcast.
examples: They're giving my favorite show!

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To estimate or predict (a duration or probability) for (something).
examples: I give it ten minutes before he gives up.
I give it a 95% chance of success.
I'll give their marriage six months.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To yield or collapse under pressure or force.
examples: Synonyms: give way, bend, cede, flex, move, yield
Antonym: resist

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lead (onto or into).
examples: The master bedroom gives onto a spacious balcony.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To provide a view of.
examples: His window gave the park.

entries.meaning: To exhibit as a product or result; to produce; to yield.
examples: The number of men, divided by the number of ships, gives four hundred to each ship.

entries.meaning: To cause; to make; used with the infinitive.
To cause (someone) to have; produce in (someone); effectuate.
To allow or admit by way of supposition; to concede.
examples: He can be bad-tempered, I'll give you that, but he's a hard worker.

entries.meaning: To attribute; to assign; to adjudge.
To communicate or announce (advice, tidings, etc.); to pronounce or utter (an opinion, a judgment, a shout, etc.).
examples: The umpire finally gave his decision: the ball was out.

entries.meaning: (dated or religion) To grant power, permission, destiny, etc. (especially to a person); to allot; to allow.
(reflexive) To devote or apply (oneself).
examples: The soldiers give themselves to plunder.
That boy is given to fits of bad temper.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To become soft or moist.
(obsolete) To shed tears; to weep.
(obsolete) To have a misgiving.
examples: My mind gives ye're reserv'd / To rob poor market women.

entries.meaning: (slang) To be going on, to be occurring; Only used in what gives?
(slang) To exceed expectations.
examples: Your outfit is giving!

entries.meaning: Alternative form of gyve
